Idiom (North Frisian): Hee hee en drak in de hööv
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with subject-verb-object structure; present tense
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone is angry or making a big scene over something minor
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To overreact or get worked up over nothing
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used across Föhr and Amrum; 'drak' (dragon) reflects exaggerated emotional outbursts
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, North Frisi: [heː heː ɛn drɑk ɪn də høːv]
First Example Sentence: Aalst hee hee en drak in de hööv, wan de tee ween't wärm jenooch.
Second Example Sentence: Wat bist dü för en Minsken, jümmers hee hee en drak in de hööv?
Third Example Sentence: Ik hee keen Tied för hee hee en drak in de hööv, lat üs mol rooch bliw.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something is very uncomfortable or unpleasant

Second Example Sentence: De Nääwel bäädt as en Stian hüt moarn.
Third Example Sentence: Dat Büx bäädt as en Stian, koft önj’t Fäärgduch.

Idiom (North Frisian): Jüst as en Aal in'n Bäärg
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Simile with prepositional phrase; nominal comparison
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone is completely out of place or uncomfortable
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To feel out of place or not belong
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Föhr-based simile; eels and mountains are ecologically incompatible
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, North Frisi: [jyst as ɛn ʔaːl ɪn ən bɛːrk]
First Example Sentence: Ik fühl mi jüst as en Aal in’n Bäärg in dissen Meetung.
Second Example Sentence: Hii wiar jüst as en Aal in’n Bäärg in’t Balett.
Third Example Sentence: As dü önj de Stadt gungst, wiarst dü jüst as en Aal in’n Bäärg.

Idiom (North Frisian): Slape as en Snak efter somer
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Simile with temporal marker; stative structure
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Metaphor from hibernating snakes, common in Föhr tales
First Example Sentence: De Buu slapt as en Snak efter somer.
Second Example Sentence: Ik hee slapt as en Snak efter somer na’t Fest.
Third Example Sentence: Et wiar stil, all slapt as en Snak efter somer.

Idiom (North Frisian): Et käämt di as en Koog över
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Impersonal clause with simile and prepositional phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something arrives suddenly and powerfully, often emotionally
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: It hits you hard or overwhelms you
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to sudden flooding in the Koog (polder) regions
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, North Frisi: [ɛt kɛːmt di as ɛn koːk øːvər]
First Example Sentence: Et käämt mi as en Koog över, wan ik hörte det Nais.
Second Example Sentence: Dat Trüüd käämt em as en Koog över.
Third Example Sentence: Et käämt di as en Koog över, wan’t harmlos üüb’t Maal kümmt.

Idiom (North Frisian): Gung ütj as en Licht in de Wind
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Simile with prepositional clause; past tense
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Something disappeared or ended suddenly and quietly
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Lighthouses and storm imagery common in coastal Frisian tales
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, North Frisi: [gʊŋ ʏtʃ as ɛn lɪçt ɪn də vɪnt]
First Example Sentence: De aalt Leew gung ütj as en Licht in de Wind.
Second Example Sentence: Al’s Hoffnungen gung ütj as en Licht in de Wind.
Third Example Sentence: Dat Droom wiar fääl – gung ütj as en Licht in de Wind.

Idiom (North Frisian): Hee en Muus op de Tung
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with object prepositional phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To stay quiet when one has something to say
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Mouse-on-tongue motif found in children's tales from Amrum

Second Example Sentence: Hii hee en Muus op de Tung, wan’t Spel begann.
Third Example Sentence: Lat jü spreeken – du heest en Muus op de Tung!
